author: Denys Bucksten
title: Some fans confident despite Cubs' NLCS series opening loss Lake County News-Sun
text:
If the Cubs faithful were nervous as the National League Championship Series started Saturday night, many of them hid it well.
Fans watching the start of the series at home, in sports bars and at work seemed to have gained the optimism of youth — embodied in five rookie starters on the 2015 Cubs.
Amy and Paul Elloian were calm in the bottom of the first as the Mets took a 1-0 lead and took in stride the 1-1 tie score in the top of the fifth. That the game ended in a 4-2 Mets win was not cause for alarm, either.
When the Cubs play, home or away, said Amy Elloian, "I have 98 percent confidence that they can come back. Just look at them. They are casual yet confident. And (Cubs' Manager Joe) Maddon makes sure they are relaxed.
Lake County Cubs fans Denys Bucksten / Lake County News-Sun With a waiting line out the door, Cubs playoff fever heats up at Buffalo Wild Wings in Waukegan an hour before the first pitch Saturday night, Oct. 17, 2015. (Denys Bucksten/ News-Sun) With a waiting line out the door, Cubs playoff fever heats up at Buffalo Wild Wings in Waukegan an hour before the first pitch Saturday night, Oct. 17, 2015. (Denys Bucksten/ News-Sun) (Denys Bucksten / Lake County News-Sun) "I think that may be what they might need to get to the World Series. They might not win it, but I think they will get there."
Added husband Paul, "The Cubs are a whole new organization, with the Ricketts family. They have increased the front office, scouting and with the Dominican Republic organization, one-third of the players are from there."
At Buffalo Wild Wings Bar & Grill in Waukegan, patrons, including some in Cubs regalia, were lined out the door an hour before game time. General Manager John Durso said "Cub fans are truly fanatical about it. They love their team and come in all the time. It really is a great environment here for them to watch the game.
"They cheer, yell and it's great for the city, too," he added. "After the wins the fans have a lot of fun here with the celebrations."
Cubs fan Laurel Herman of Mundelein has been following the North Siders since she was a little girl, when her father would turn on the games on the radio. If she and her siblings visited their grandmother in the country, "We'd huddle around the radio we could hear everything," she said.
Some habits die hard, said Herman, who prefers to watch the Cubs on television but listen to the play-by-play on the radio.
Lake County Cubs fans Denys Bucksten / Lake County News-Sun Employees at Mike's Pizza have little opportunity to glance at the television as orders flood in at the carryout restaurant in Waukegan on Saturday, Oct. 17, 2015. (Denys Bucksten/ News-Sun) Employees at Mike's Pizza have little opportunity to glance at the television as orders flood in at the carryout restaurant in Waukegan on Saturday, Oct. 17, 2015. (Denys Bucksten/ News-Sun) (Denys Bucksten / Lake County News-Sun) "If we were in the car when a game was on the car radio," said Herman, "I would stand up on the back seat for the national anthem."
And she prefers to watch the games alone, at home, to concentrate on every play without any distractions. "But when they beat the Cardinals I ran out into my backyard and screamed 'Cubs win! Cubs win! Cubs win!'" Herman said.
"And then my kids each called me, from Georgia, Hampshire (Il.) and Wildwood. It was awesome that each one of them called me right after the game," said Herman.
"Whatever the Cubs do, I still love them," she added.
Denys Bucksten is a freelance reporter for the News-Sun.
